procedures.name: Paracentesis
procedures.indications: New-onset ascites. Fluid evaluation helps to determine etiology, differentiate transudate versus exudate, detect the presence of cancerous cells, or address other considerations. Suspected spontaneous or secondary bacterial peritonitis. Refractory ascites
procedures.method: Switch to the longer 20-gauge needle, and administer 4-5 mL of lidocaine along the catheter insertion tract (see the image below). Make sure to anesthetize all the way down to the peritoneum. The authors recommend alternating injection and intermittent aspiration down the tract until ascitic fluid is noticed in the syringe. Note the depth at which the peritoneum is entered. In obese patients, reaching the peritoneum may involve passing through a significant amount of adipose tissue
procedures.complications: Failed attempt to collect peritoneal fluid. Persistent leak from the puncture site. Wound infection. Abdominal wall hematoma. Spontaneous hemoperitoneum. This rare complication is due to mesenteric variceal bleeding after removal of a large amount of ascitic fluid. Hollow viscus perforation (small or large bowel, stomach, bladder). Catheter laceration and loss in abdominal cavity. Laceration of major blood vessel (aorta, mesenteric artery, iliac artery). Postparacentesis hypotension. Dilutional hyponatremia. Hepatorenal syndrome

procedures.name: Radiation
procedures.indications: Radiation therapy may be used on its own to treat prostate cancer or a tumor of the larynx. Radiation therapy may be carried out before or during cancer surgery to shrink the tumor, or after surgery to reduce the risk that all cancer cells have not been removed. Relieving pressure or blockage by reducing tumor size. Treating symptoms of brain cancer, such as headaches, nausea, and dizziness. Reducing symptoms of lung cancer, such as chest pain and breathlessness controlling ulcerating tumors, bleeding, and infections
procedures.method: In external radiation therapy, a machine called a linear accelerator is used to emit X-rays within a specific energy range. Other machines are also available that use other forms of energy, including electrons, protons, gamma rays, or a combination of these. Internal radiation therapy involves an implant of metal tubes, wires, or seeds that can be placed inside the body without surgery. In some cases, surgery may be needed to locate the implant nearer to the cancer.
procedures.complications: Fatigue or Lethargy, skin irritation, including swelling, blisters, and a sunburned or tanned appearance. Effects specific to the area of treatment, such as hair loss, urinary problems, nausea,vomiting, and diarrhea. Tissue inflammation, such as esophagitis, pneumonitis, and hepatitis. Rarely, a drop in the number of white blood cells or platelets

procedures.name: Structured Intermittent Auscultation
procedures.indications: Assess FHR before: initiation of labor-enhancing procedure; ambulation of patient; administration of medications; or initiation of analgesia or anesthesia. Assess FHR after: admission of patient; artificial or spontaneous rupture of membranes; vaginal examination; abnormal uterine activity; or evaluation of analgesia or anesthesia
procedures.method: Palpate the abdomen to determine the position of the fetus (Leopold maneuvers). Place the Doppler over the area of maximal intensity of fetal heart tones. Differentiate maternal pulse from fetal pulse. Palpate for uterine contraction during period of FHR auscultation to determine relationship. Count FHR between contractions for â‰¥ 60 seconds to determine average baseline rate. Count FHR after uterine contraction for 60 seconds (at 5-second intervals) to identify fetal response to active labor (this may be subject to local protocols)

procedures.name: CRRT
procedures.indications: Intractable hyperkalaemia. Acidosis. Uraemic symptoms (nausea, pruritus, malaise).Therapy-resistant fluid overload. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 5
procedures.method: Haemodialysis (HD) involves circulating blood through a disposable dialyser. The vascular access of choice is the arteriovenous fistula (AVF). This, however, requires suitable peripheral veins and needs four to eight weeks for the fistula to mature. If there are no suitable veins, a graft can usually be inserted. Acute access with venous catheters has a high complication rate.Peritoneal dialysis (PD) involves using the peritoneum as the dialysis membrane, with pre-packaged fluid being instilled into the peritoneal space via a Tenckhoff catheter. This is usually only inserted once the decision to start dialysis is made.
procedures.complications: Bleeding. Vessel damage. Bloodstream or localised infection. Air embolis. Hypoxia. Haemodynamic instability Hypocapnea. Hypothermia. Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. Electrolyte disturbance. Hypocalcemia with citrate toxicity. Complications related to anticoagulation

procedures.name: Cystoscopy
procedures.indications: It is often used to find causes of bleeding or blockage, or any abnormalities of the bladder and its lining.
procedures.method: The cystoscope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder. The cystoscope is a thin, lighted tube with lenses. Most often it is bendable, but some models are rigid. Water or saline is infused through the cystoscope into the bladder. As the fluid fills the bladder, the bladder wall is stretched so the urologist can see clearly.
procedures.complications: Infection. Rarely, cystoscopy can introduce germs into your urinary tract, causing infection. Bleeding. Cystoscopy might cause some blood in your urine. Pain. You might experience abdominal pain and a burning sensation when urinating.

medications.name: Tacrolimus
medications.indications: For use after allogenic organ transplant to reduce the activity of the patient's immune system and so the risk of organ rejection
medications.mechanism: Exact mechanism of action unknown; inhibits T-lymphocyte activation

medications.name: mycophenolate mofetil
medications.indications: Used with other medicines to prevent organ rejection after a kidney, liver, or heart transplant
medications.mechanism: Inhibits B- and T-lymphocyte proliferation

medications.name: rituximab
medications.indications: An immunotherapy medicine that interferes with the growth and spread of cancer cells and helps prevent rejection of transplanted organs in the body.
medications.mechanism: Binds to B-lymphocyte CD20 surface antigens (monoclonal antibody)

medications.name: cyclosporine
medications.indications: Used to prevent organ rejection after a kidney, heart, or liver transplant.
medications.mechanism: Exact mechanism of action unknown; inhibits T-lymphocytes

medications.name: sirolimus
medications.indications: Used to prevent organ rejection after a kidney, heart, or liver transplant.
medications.mechanism: Inhibits T-lymphocyte activation and proliferation, and inhibits antibody production; inhibits mTOR signaling pathway, inhibiting proliferation of lymphangioleiomyomatosis cells and preventing release of lymphangiogenic growth factors

medications.name: cisplatin
medications.indications: Testicular and Ovarian Carcinoma
medications.mechanism: Death of rapidly growing cells, particularly malignant ones

medications.name: methotrexate
medications.indications: Used to treat leukemia and certain types of cancer of the breast, skin, head and neck, or lung
medications.mechanism: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase; inhibits lymphocyte proliferation (folate antagonist)

medications.name: doxorubicin
medications.indications: Used to treat different types of cancers that affect the breast, bladder, ovary, thyroid, stomach, lungs, bones, nerve tissues, muscles, joints, and soft tissues. Doxorubicin is also used to treat Hodgkin's disease and certain types of leukemia
medications.mechanism: Binds and intercalates into DNA, inhibiting nucleic acid and protein synthesis; triggers DNA cleavage by topoisomerase II

medications.name: megestrol
medications.indications: Used to treat loss of appetite and wasting syndrome in people with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).
medications.mechanism: Exact mechanism of action unknown; agonizes glucocorticoid receptors; may interfere with cachexin (progestin)

medications.name: etoposide
medications.indications: Used to treat small cell lung cancer. It is usually given in combination with other cancer medicines
medications.mechanism: Affects cell cycle G2, lysing cells entering mitosis and inhibiting cells from entering prophase

medications.name: oxytocin
medications.indications: Used to induce labor or strengthen labor contractions during childbirth, and to control bleeding after childbirth
medications.mechanism: Binds to oxytocin receptors in myometrium, increasing intracellular Ca and stimulating uterine contractions

medications.name: magnesium sulfate
medications.indications: Used to prevent seizures in pregnant women with conditions such as pre-eclampsia, eclampsia, or toxemia of pregnancy
medications.mechanism: Participates in physiologic processes

medications.name: Salbutamol
medications.indications: Uncomplicated premature labour between 24â€“33 weeks gestation
medications.mechanism: Participates in physiologic processes

medications.name: misoprostol
medications.indications: Reduces stomach acid and helps protect the stomach from damage that can be caused by taking a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug
medications.mechanism: Inhibits gastric acid secretion and protects GI mucosa; produces uterine contractions (prostaglandin E1)

medications.name: bupivacaine
medications.indications: Regional anesthesia during childbirth
medications.mechanism: Inhibits Na ion channels, stabilizing neuronal cell membranes and inhibiting nerve impulse initiation and conduction

medications.name: propofol
medications.indications: Used to sedate a patient who is under critical care and needs a mechanical ventilator
medications.mechanism: Induces hypnosis

medications.name: norepinephrine
medications.indications: Used to treat life-threatening low blood pressure (hypotension)
medications.mechanism: Stimulates alpha and beta-1 adrenergic receptors; produces inotropic and vasopressor effects

medications.name: nitroprusside
medications.indications: Hypertensive Crisis or high blood pressure
medications.mechanism: Directly dilates peripheral vessels

medications.name: vasopressin
medications.indications: Helps prevent loss of water from the body by reducing urine output and helping the kidneys reabsorb water into the body. Vasopressin also raises blood pressure by narrowing blood vessels.
medications.mechanism: Directly stimulates V1 and V2 receptors, resulting in vasoconstriction and antidiuresis

medications.name: dexmedetomidine
medications.indications: A sedative that is used to sedate a patient who is under intensive medical care and needs a mechanical ventilator
medications.mechanism: Produces centrally mediated sympatholytic, sedative and analgesic effects (selective alpha-2 adrenergic agonist)

medications.name: phenazopyridine
medications.indications: used to treat urinary symptoms such as pain or burning, increased urination, and increased urge to urinate. These symptoms can be caused by infection, injury, surgery, catheter, or other conditions that irritate the bladder
medications.mechanism: Produces topical analgesia

medications.name: flavoxate
medications.indications: Bladder Spasms
medications.mechanism: Antagonizes acetylcholine receptors (anticholinergic)

medications.name: oxybutynin
medications.indications: Reduces muscle spasms of the bladder and urinary tract.
medications.mechanism: Antagonizes acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors; relaxes bladder smooth muscle, inhibits involuntary detrusor muscle contractions (anticholinergic)

medications.name: finasteride
medications.indications: Used to treat symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in men with an enlarged prostate
medications.mechanism: Inhibits type II 5-alpha-reductase, interfering w/ conversion of testosterone to 5-alpha-dihydrotestosterone

medications.name: tamsulosin
medications.indications: Used to improve urination in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate
medications.mechanism: Selectively antagonizes prostate alpha-1a adrenergic receptors, relaxing smooth muscle and improving urine flow (peripherally-acting alpha blocker)
